front: What is modulation?
back: Modulation is changing a wave (carrier) so it can carry data, like voice or internet signals.

front: What is a carrier wave?
back: A high-frequency wave that is changed (modulated) to carry information.

front: What is a modulating signal?
back: The original data (like audio or digital bits) that changes the carrier wave.

front: What changes in Amplitude Modulation (AM)?
back: The height of the carrier wave (amplitude) changes based on the data.

front: What changes in Frequency Modulation (FM)?
back: The closeness of the wave peaks (frequency) changes based on the data.

front: Why are twisted pair cables twisted?
back: Twisting cancels out electromagnetic noise to keep the signal clear.

front: What does UTP stand for?
back: Unshielded Twisted Pair – a common cable type with no extra shielding.

front: How is Cat5e better than Cat5?
back: Cat5e has tighter specs to reduce crosstalk and supports faster speeds (up to 1 Gbps).

front: What is a cut-off frequency?
back: The point in a filter where it starts reducing unwanted frequencies.

front: What is QAM?
back: Quadrature Amplitude Modulation – sends data by changing both amplitude (height) and phase (timing) of a wave.

front: What is the purpose of a filter in signal transmission?
back: A filter allows certain frequencies to pass and blocks others to clean up a signal.

front: What does a low-pass filter do?
back: It passes low frequencies and blocks high frequencies above a set point.

front: What does a high-pass filter do?
back: It passes high frequencies and blocks low frequencies below a set point.

front: What is a band-pass filter?
back: It allows a specific range of frequencies through and blocks all others.

front: What is the envelope in AM?
back: The outer shape of the AM wave that matches the modulating signal.

front: Why is FM less affected by noise than AM?
back: FM ignores changes in amplitude, which is where most noise happens.

front: What is crosstalk in cables?
back: Unwanted signals from nearby cables interfering with your signal.

front: What is Alien Crosstalk?
back: Interference caused by signals from nearby cables, not the pairs inside the same cable.

front: Why is Cat6a better than Cat6 for 10 Gbps?
back: Cat6a supports 10 Gbps up to 100 meters, with better shielding to reduce noise.

front: What is the main benefit of LSZH cable?
back: It releases less smoke and no toxic gas when burned – safer in fires.

front: What does shielding in Ethernet cables do?
back: It protects the signal from external noise like EMI and RFI.

front: What does EMI stand for?
back: Electromagnetic Interference – unwanted electrical noise that can distort signals.

front: What is the difference between STP and UTP?
back: STP has shielding to block noise; UTP has no shielding and relies on twisting.

front: What is the main advantage of using STP cables?
back: They reduce interference and support higher data rates over longer distances.

front: What does 'Cat' stand for in Ethernet cables?
back: 'Cat' means 'Category' – it shows the cable's performance level and standards.

front: What is the maximum length for standard Ethernet cables (Cat5e/Cat6)?
back: 100 meters (for reliable data transmission without a repeater).

front: What happens to a square wave as it passes through a low-pass filter?
back: It loses sharp edges because high-frequency parts are filtered out.

front: Why are higher category cables stiffer?
back: They have tighter twists and thicker shielding, making them less flexible.

front: What does S/FTP mean in cable shielding?
back: It has a braid shield around the cable and foil around each twisted pair.

front: Why is twisting important in twisted pair cables?
back: Twisting cancels out interference by balancing the electrical noise between the wires.

front: What does F/UTP stand for?
back: Foil over Unshielded Twisted Pairs – overall foil shield, no shielding on individual pairs.

front: What does U/FTP stand for?
back: Unshielded cable with Foil around each Twisted Pair – good protection against crosstalk.

front: What does SF/UTP mean?
back: Shielded and Foiled over Unshielded Twisted Pairs – braid + foil shield around the whole cable.

front: What does F/FTP stand for?
back: Foil shield around the whole cable and also foil around each twisted pair.

front: What does S/FTP stand for?
back: Braid shield over the cable and foil shielding around each twisted pair.

front: What does SF/FTP stand for?
back: Braid and foil around the whole cable, plus foil around each twisted pair – maximum shielding.

front: Which shielding type gives the best protection from EMI?
back: SF/FTP – it has braid + foil outside and foil around each pair.

front: What type of Ethernet cable is best for very noisy environments?
back: Shielded cables like S/FTP or SF/FTP are best in high interference areas.

front: Which cable type is most commonly used in LANs?
back: U/UTP (Unshielded Twisted Pair) – it's cheap, easy to install, and works well for most networks.

front: Why is Cat8 cable only used in short runs?
back: It supports very high speeds (40 Gbps) but only over short distances (up to 30 meters).

front: What type of cable is recommended for backbone cabling in large buildings?
back: Multimode or singlemode optical fiber – it supports high speed over long distances.

front: What is the max length allowed for horizontal cabling?
back: 90 meters, plus up to 10 meters total for patch cables.

front: Which cable type is typically used for horizontal cabling today?
back: Cat6 or Cat6a – supports Gigabit and 10 Gigabit Ethernet.

front: What cable type is commonly used in the work area for PCs and phones?
back: Cat5e or Cat6 patch cables – short, flexible, and match the main horizontal cable.

front: What cabling is used in the entrance facility?
back: Shielded twisted pair or fiber – protects against interference and supports external connections.

front: Why is fiber preferred for backbone cabling?
back: It supports longer distances and higher speeds with less signal loss.

front: What is typically found in the telecommunications room?
back: Patch panels, switches, and connections between horizontal and backbone cabling.

front: Why is LSZH cable used in structured cabling?
back: It’s safer in fires – produces less smoke and no toxic gases.

front: What cable type is best for short high-speed links in the equipment room?
back: Cat6a or fiber – both support high bandwidth and low delay.

front: What is the main difference between backbone and horizontal cabling?
back: Backbone connects floors/buildings; horizontal connects rooms on the same floor.

front: What is structured cabling?
back: A standardized way to install and organize network cables in buildings using subsystems.

front: Name the six subsystems of structured cabling.
back: Entrance facility, equipment room, backbone cabling, horizontal cabling, telecommunications room, work area.

front: What is the purpose of the equipment room?
back: It houses core network hardware like servers, routers, and patch panels.

front: What is insertion loss?
back: The amount of signal strength lost as it travels through a cable – measured in dB.

front: How does frequency affect insertion loss?
back: Higher frequencies experience more insertion loss than lower ones.

front: What does the TIA/EIA-568 standard define?
back: Rules for designing and installing commercial structured cabling systems.

front: What is the difference between T568A and T568B wiring?
back: They are two color code standards for wiring Ethernet jacks and cables.

front: What happens if you mix T568A and T568B wiring?
back: It creates a crossover cable – useful in some cases, but can cause errors if done accidentally.

front: Why is fiber better for EMI-prone environments?
back: Fiber is immune to electromagnetic interference and signal leakage.

front: What does a TDR (Time Domain Reflectometer) do?
back: It sends a signal into a cable and checks for reflections to find breaks or shorts and measure cable length.

front: What is an open in a cable?
back: A break where the wire is not connected; shows a positive reflection on a TDR.

front: What is a short in a cable?
back: Two conductors are touching; shows a negative reflection on a TDR.

front: What is wiremap testing?
back: A check to ensure each wire is connected pin-for-pin correctly at both ends.

front: What does insertion loss mean?
back: The signal strength lost as it passes through a cable; measured in decibels (dB).

front: What is NEXT (Near End Crosstalk)?
back: Signal interference measured near the transmitting end of the cable.

front: What is FEXT (Far End Crosstalk)?
back: Signal interference measured at the far (receiving) end of the cable.

front: What is PSNEXT (Power Sum NEXT)?
back: A calculated total of crosstalk from all other pairs onto one pair.

front: What is AXT (Alien Crosstalk)?
back: Interference caused by signals from nearby cables, not inside the same cable.

front: What does cable skew mean?
back: The time delay difference between the fastest and slowest wire pairs in a cable.

front: What is propagation delay?
back: The time it takes for a signal to travel from one end of a cable to the other.

front: What unit is insertion loss measured in?
back: Decibels (dB).

front: What unit is propagation delay measured in?
back: Nanoseconds (ns).

front: What tool is typically used to perform a wiremap test?
back: A cable certifier or tester with wiremap function.

front: Why is PSNEXT important for Gigabit Ethernet?
back: Because Gigabit Ethernet uses all four pairs, and PSNEXT checks total interference across them.

front: What is the maximum delay skew allowed in a standard Ethernet cable?
back: 50 nanoseconds (ns).

front: How is cable length calculated with a TDR?
back: By measuring the round-trip time of a pulse and multiplying by signal speed.

front: What causes attenuation?
back: Cable length, wire thickness, damage, and frequency – signal weakens over distance.

front: What is the typical signal speed used for cable length calculations?
back: Approximately 166,000,000 meters per second.

front: What happens if insertion loss is too high?
back: The signal may not be readable at the other end, causing errors or failure.

front: What does a positive reflection from a TDR indicate?
back: An open circuit – the cable is broken or disconnected.

front: What does a negative reflection from a TDR indicate?
back: A short circuit – two wires are touching or connected improperly.

front: How does wire twist affect NEXT?
back: Tighter twisting reduces NEXT by canceling out interference between pairs.

front: Why must twist be maintained near connectors?
back: Untwisting near terminations increases crosstalk and reduces performance.

front: What happens if delay skew is too high?
back: The pairs arrive at different times, breaking high-speed data communication.

front: How does cable length affect insertion loss?
back: Longer cables cause more loss – insertion loss increases with length.

front: What does a wiremap test NOT detect?
back: It does not check bandwidth or signal quality – only wiring layout.

front: What is the typical test frequency range for NEXT?
back: From 1 MHz up to 100 MHz or higher, depending on cable category.

front: Why is AXT a concern in 10 Gbps networks?
back: High-frequency signals can leak between cables, corrupting nearby links.

front: Why are patch panels also a risk for AXT?
back: Multiple tightly spaced cables and connectors can cause signal leakage between links.

front: What might cause a high NEXT failure during certification?
back: Untwisted pairs near connectors, poor termination, or wrong category patch cords.

front: What causes high insertion loss?
back: Long cable runs, damaged cables, thin wire gauge, or excessive bends.

front: If a cable fails a wiremap test, what’s likely wrong?
back: There may be miswiring, open wires, shorts, reversed pairs, or split pairs.

front: Why would delay skew fail on a cable?
back: Different pair lengths, incorrect cable twist rates, or bad manufacturing.

front: How can alien crosstalk be reduced in patch panels?
back: By separating cables, using shielded patch panels, and managing cable spacing.

front: What could cause a TDR to show a short at the far end?
back: The cable pairs are improperly punched or touching at the termination point.

front: Why might a link pass wiremap but still fail certification?
back: Because wiremap only checks wiring layout — not signal quality like NEXT or attenuation.

front: How does over-bending a cable affect test results?
back: It increases insertion loss and may cause return loss or impedance mismatch.

front: What is the likely issue if a link fails only at higher frequencies?
back: Crosstalk, poor shielding, or cable quality not supporting the rated category.

front: What should you do if a Cat6 cable fails the delay skew test?
back: Replace the cable – pair imbalance likely can't be fixed manually.

front: What is attenuation?
back: The loss of signal strength as it travels through a medium like fiber or copper.

front: What is electromagnetic interference (EMI)?
back: Disruption caused by nearby electrical devices that affects copper signals but not fiber.

front: What is crosstalk in copper cabling?
back: Unwanted signal interference between adjacent wire pairs.

front: What is fiber optic cable?
back: A cable that transmits data as light through thin glass or plastic strands.

front: What is copper cabling?
back: Cabling that uses electrical current through metal wires to transmit data.

front: What is single-mode fiber used for?
back: Long-distance, high-speed transmission — up to 40 km.

front: What is multimode fiber used for?
back: Shorter distances — typically 300 to 550 meters depending on speed.

front: What is the maximum distance for copper Ethernet cabling?
back: 100 meters — includes 90 meters of horizontal cable and 10 meters of patch cables.

front: What is Cat8 cable's maximum distance?
back: 30 meters — used for short high-speed links up to 40 Gbps.

front: What is insertion loss?
back: Signal power lost due to the cable or connectors in the path — measured in dB.

front: What is fiber optic cable?
back: A cable that uses light to transmit data through thin glass or plastic strands.

front: What is the core in fiber optic cable?
back: The center part of the fiber where light travels.

front: What is the cladding in fiber optics?
back: The outer layer that reflects light back into the core to keep it inside.

front: What is total internal reflection?
back: The process that keeps light bouncing inside the core without escaping.

front: What is the main use of singlemode fiber?
back: High-speed, long-distance data transmission — up to 40+ km.

front: What is the main use of multimode fiber?
back: Short to medium distances — typically 300–550 meters in LANs.

front: What does OM3 refer to?
back: Laser-optimized multimode fiber that supports 10 Gbps up to 300 meters.

front: What causes attenuation in fibre?
back: Loss of signal due to absorption, scattering, or bending of light.

front: What is modal dispersion?
back: Signal distortion caused by different light paths (modes) in multimode fibre.

front: What is chromatic dispersion?
back: Signal spreading caused by different light wavelengths traveling at different speeds.

front: What are the typical wavelengths used in fiber optics?
back: 850 nm, 1300 nm, and 1550 nm — these are in the infrared range because they have lower signal loss.

front: Why are infrared wavelengths used in fiber optics?
back: Because they cause less signal loss (attenuation) than visible light wavelengths.

front: What light source is used in multimode fiber?
back: An LED — cheaper, slower, and only works with multimode fiber.

front: What light source is used in singlemode fiber?
back: A laser — high speed, precise beam, used for long distances.

front: What is Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM)?
back: A method that sends multiple light signals over one fiber using different wavelengths.

front: What is the purpose of WDM?
back: It increases the amount of data that can be sent through one fiber by using different wavelengths.

front: What is a macrobend in fiber?
back: A large bend that causes the light to escape the core, leading to signal loss.

front: What is a microbend in fiber?
back: Tiny bends or pressure points that disrupt the light path, often caused by poor installation or pressure.

front: Why is installing fiber cable more difficult than copper?
back: Fiber is more fragile, needs precise alignment, and special tools for termination and testing.

front: Why is it dangerous to look into a fiber connector?
back: The laser or LED is invisible and could damage your eye, even though you can't see the light.

front: What is OM1 fiber?
back: An older multimode fiber with a 62.5 µm core, supports up to 33 m at 10 Gbps.

front: What is OM2 fiber?
back: A 50 µm multimode fiber that supports around 82 m at 10 Gbps.

front: What is OM3 fiber?
back: Laser-optimized 50 µm multimode fiber that supports 10 Gbps up to 300 m.

front: What is OM4 fiber?
back: Improved OM3 that supports 10 Gbps up to 550 m and 100 Gbps at shorter distances.

front: What is OM5 fiber?
back: Wideband multimode fiber designed for high-speed and multiple wavelengths — supports 100 Gbps.

front: What is dispersion in fiber optics?
back: When light pulses spread out during transmission, which can cause distortion and data loss.

front: What is modal dispersion?
back: Happens in multimode fiber when different light paths take different times to arrive.

front: What is chromatic dispersion?
back: Happens when different wavelengths of light travel at slightly different speeds.

front: Why is dispersion a problem?
back: It makes signals overlap and harder to read at the receiver end — especially at high speeds.

front: How can dispersion be reduced?
back: Use singlemode fiber or lasers that emit just one wavelength of light.

front: What is attenuation in fiber optics?
back: It's the loss of signal strength as light travels through the fiber. Measured in dB/km.

front: What is dispersion in fiber optics?
back: It’s when the light signal spreads out over time, which can cause distortion and overlap.

front: What is modal dispersion?
back: A type of dispersion where different light paths arrive at different times in multimode fiber.

front: What is chromatic dispersion?
back: A type of dispersion where different wavelengths (colors) of light travel at slightly different speeds.

front: What is refraction in fiber optics?
back: It’s how light bends when it enters a different material, like from air into glass.

front: What is total internal reflection?
back: It's the process that keeps light bouncing inside the fiber core so it stays trapped and moves forward.

front: What is scattering in fiber optics?
back: Some of the light bounces in random directions because of imperfections — this causes minor signal loss.

front: What causes absorption in fiber?
back: Some light energy is absorbed by impurities like OH⁻ ions in the glass, causing signal loss.

front: What is macrobend loss?
back: Signal loss caused by bending the fiber too sharply, letting light escape from the core.

front: What is microbend loss?
back: Tiny bends or pressure spots in the fiber that scatter the light and reduce signal strength.

front: What is Wi-Fi?
back: A technology for wireless networking that uses radio waves, based on the IEEE 802.11 family of standards.

front: What is an Access Point (AP)?
back: A device that creates a wireless local area network (WLAN), allowing Wi-Fi devices to connect to a wired network.

front: What is an SSID?
back: Service Set Identifier (SSID) — The name that identifies a specific Wi-Fi network, broadcast by an access point.

front: What frequency bands are used by Wi-Fi?
back: The radio frequency bands used by Wi-Fi: 2.4 GHz, 5 GHz, and the newer 6 GHz band (introduced with Wi-Fi 6E and Wi-Fi 7).

front: What is MIMO in wireless networking?
back: Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) — A technology using multiple antennas at both the transmitter and receiver to improve wireless performance and increase data capacity.

front: What is MU-MIMO?
back: Multi-User MIMO (MU-MIMO) — An enhancement to MIMO that allows an access point to communicate with multiple compatible devices simultaneously.

front: What is beamforming?
back: A signal processing technique where a wireless transmitter focuses the radio signal towards a specific receiving device, improving signal strength and performance.

front: What is QAM?
back: Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) — A digital modulation scheme that encodes data by changing both the amplitude and phase of a carrier wave, allowing more data to be transmitted.

front: What is channel bonding?
back: Combining adjacent Wi-Fi channels into a single wider channel to increase data throughput and bandwidth (e.g., combining 20 MHz channels to create 40 MHz, 80 MHz, or 160 MHz channels).

front: What is the main purpose of WPA2 or WPA3?
back: Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA2 or WPA3) — Security protocols used to secure wireless networks by encrypting data and controlling access, preventing unauthorized use.

front: What is Wi-Fi 4 also called?
back: 802.11n — it works on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz and supports up to 600 Mbps.

front: What is Wi-Fi 5 also called?
back: 802.11ac — it uses 5 GHz and supports up to 3.5 Gbps.

front: What is Wi-Fi 6 also called?
back: 802.11ax — supports faster speeds, more devices, and works on 2.4 and 5 GHz.

front: What is Wi-Fi 6E?
back: An extended version of Wi-Fi 6 that also uses the 6 GHz band for less interference.

front: What is Wi-Fi 7?
back: 802.11be — a new generation using 2.4, 5, and 6 GHz with speeds up to 46 Gbps.

front: What is free space path loss?
back: Signal strength drops as it travels further — even with no obstacles.

front: How does reflection affect Wi-Fi?
back: Signals can bounce off surfaces and cause interference or delays (multipath).

front: What causes Wi-Fi absorption?
back: Materials like walls, floors, and even people can absorb signal energy and weaken the signal.

front: What is the purpose of a site survey?
back: To measure Wi-Fi coverage and find the best places to install access points.

front: Where should you place a Wi-Fi access point?
back: High and central, away from metal or thick walls, for the best coverage.

front: What is WEP?
back: The original Wi-Fi security standard — weak and outdated.

front: What is WPA?
back: A security improvement over WEP — still has known flaws.

front: What is WPA2?
back: A strong Wi-Fi security protocol using AES encryption — still widely used today.

front: What is WPA3?
back: The latest Wi-Fi security standard — offers stronger encryption and protection against password guessing.

front: What is a Wi-Fi extender?
back: A device that rebroadcasts the Wi-Fi signal to cover a larger area.

front: What is a mesh Wi-Fi system?
back: A group of access points working together to provide seamless coverage across a large area.

front: What is the 1-6-11 rule in 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi?
back: Use channels 1, 6, or 11 to avoid overlap and reduce interference.

front: Why does Wi-Fi slow down with more users?
back: All users on the same AP share bandwidth — more devices = less speed per device.

front: What household items can interfere with Wi-Fi?
back: Microwave ovens, cordless phones, baby monitors, and Bluetooth devices.

front: Why is 5 GHz less crowded than 2.4 GHz?
back: It has more channels and fewer devices use it, so there’s less interference.

front: What is attenuation?
back: Loss of signal strength as it travels through a cable or medium.

front: What is crosstalk?
back: Interference from one cable pair to another, usually due to signal leakage.

front: What does NEXT stand for?
back: Near-End Crosstalk — interference measured at the transmitting end of the cable.

front: What is dispersion in fiber optics?
back: Spreading of a light signal over time, making it harder to detect data clearly.

front: Difference between chromatic and modal dispersion?
back: Chromatic: different light colors arrive at different times. Modal: light rays take different paths.

front: What is a Time Domain Reflectometer (TDR)?
back: A tool that finds cable faults by sending a signal and checking what bounces back.

front: What is S/FTP cable?
back: Shielded with Foil Twisted Pairs — each pair is shielded and the whole cable is also shielded.

front: Why is fiber better over long distances?
back: Fiber has low signal loss (attenuation) and no EMI issues.

front: What is the wavelength formula?
back: Wavelength = Speed / Frequency

front: What is the speed of a signal in copper?
back: About 200,000 km/s, or 2/3 the speed of light:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

front: What is OM1 fiber?
back: Old multimode fiber with a 62.5 µm core — supports short distances at low speeds.

front: What is OM5 fiber?
back: Latest multimode fiber type that supports 100 Gbps and multiple wavelengths.

front: What is FEXT?
back: Far-End Crosstalk — interference measured at the receiving end of a cable.

front: What is QAM?
back: Quadrature Amplitude Modulation — changes both signal height and timing to send data.

front: What does a positive reflection on a TDR mean?
back: An open circuit — the signal hit a break and bounced back.

front: What does a negative reflection on a TDR mean?
back: A short circuit — wires are touching and reflecting energy back.

front: What is insertion loss?
back: The amount of signal lost as it passes through a cable — measured in decibels.

front: What is MAC address filtering?
back: A wireless security method that only allows devices with approved MAC addresses to connect.

front: What is signal skew?
back: When one wire pair's signal arrives later than another — can break high-speed communication.

front: What is the maximum cable length for horizontal UTP runs?
back: 90 meters plus up to 10 meters of patch cables — total 100 meters.
